contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox MLB player |name=George McQuinn |image=George McQuinn.jpeg |position=[[First baseman]] |bats=Left |throws=Left |birth_date={{Birth date|1910|5|29}} |birth_place=[[Arlington, Virginia]] |death_date={{death date and age|1978|12|24|1910|5|29}} |death_place=[[Alexandria, Virginia]] |debutdate=April 14 |debutyear=1936 |debutteam=Cincinnati Reds |finaldate=October 2 |finalyear=1948 |finalteam=New York Yankees |stat1label=[[Batting average]] |stat1value=.276 |stat2label=[[Home run]]s |stat2value=135 |stat3label=[[Runs batted in]] |stat3value=794 |teams=<nowiki></nowiki> * [[Cincinnati Reds]] ({{By|1936}}) * [[Baltimore Orioles|St. Louis Browns]] ({{By|1938}}–{{By|1945}}) * [[Philadelphia Athletics]] ({{By|1946}}) * [[New York Yankees]] ({{By|1947}}–{{By|1948}}) |highlights=<nowiki></nowiki> * 7× [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]] selection ([[1939 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1939]], [[1940 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1940]], [[1942 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1942]], [[1944 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1944]], [[1945 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1945]], [[1947 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1947]], [[1948 Major League Baseball All-Star Game|1948]]) * [[World Series]] champion ({{wsy|1947}}) }} '''George Hartley McQuinn''' (May 29, 1910 – December 24, 1978) was a left-handed [[Major League Baseball]] [[first baseman]]. ==Early life== A native of [[Arlington, Virginia]], and a graduate of Washington-Lee High School in Arlington, Virginia, ==Baseball career== During his 12-year career, McQuinn played for the [[Cincinnati Reds]] (1936), [[Baltimore Orioles|St. Louis Browns]] (1938–45), [[Oakland Athletics|Philadelphia Athletics]] (1946) and [[New York Yankees]] (1947–48), and was selected for the [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]] seven times. In 1938 he had a .324 career-high [[batting average]] with 12 [[home run]]s, 42 [[Double (baseball)|doubles]], 100 [[Run (baseball statistics)|runs]] and 82 [[Run batted in|RBI]]. In 1939, his batting average was .316 with 101 runs scored, 94 RBIs, 37 doubles, 13 [[Triple (baseball)|triples]] and 20 home runs. The following year he had 39 doubles, 10 triples and 16 home runs. In 1944, his opening-game home run gave the Browns their first victory and was their only home run in a [[World Series]] game. In 1947, at the age of 36, McQuinn hit .304 with 13 home runs and 80 RBI's, and was nominated for the [[MLB Most Valuable Player Award|MVP Award]]. He retired the following year. McQuinn had a career batting average of .276, and a total of 135 home runs and 794 RBI's in 1550 games. After retiring, he was a manager in the [[farm system]] of the [[Atlanta Braves|Boston/Milwaukee Braves]], and scouted for the [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Washington Senators]] and [[Washington Nationals|Montreal Expos]]. He was inducted into the Arlington Sports Hall of Fame in 1958 and the Virginia Sports Hall of Fame in 1978. He died in [[Alexandria, Virginia]] at the age 68. ==See also== * [[Hitting for the cycle]] ==External links== {{Baseballstats|br=m/mcquige02}} *[http://www.baseballlibrary.com/ballplayers/player.php?name=George_McQuinn_1910 Baseball Library] {{1947 New York Yankees}} {{Persondata | NAME = McQuinn, George | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American baseball player | DATE OF BIRTH = May 29, 1910 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Arlington, Virginia | DATE OF DEATH = December 24, 1978 | PLACE OF DEATH = Alexandria, Virginia }} {{DEFAULTSORT:McQuinn, George}} [[Category:1910 births]] [[Category:1978 deaths]] [[Category:People from Arlington County, Virginia]] [[Category:American League All-Stars]] [[Category:Cincinnati Reds players]] [[Category:Major League Baseball first basemen]] [[Category:Baseball players from Virginia]] [[Category:New York Yankees players]] [[Category:Philadelphia Athletics players]] [[Category:St. Louis Browns players]] [[Category:Toronto Maple Leafs (International League) players]]
